item.title: My Arcade
item.dc:creator: Vince
item.description: My father has a great and many talents, the best of which is carpentry. He has built garages, houses, and tables. Using YouTube, I found many peoples videos of how they made their own arcade systems at home and decided it would be a fun project when I had some downtime. During the winter in […]
item.content:encoded:
My father has a great and many talents, the best of which is carpentry. He has built garages, houses, and tables. Using YouTube, I found many peoples videos of how they made their own arcade systems at home and decided it would be a fun project when I had some downtime.

During the winter in 2014, with my fathers guidance and some blueprints I found online, we went to work measuring, cutting, and screwing everything together for a arcade system with series of draws in the back and shelves for more commonly used items.

After the frame was done, I started on the part that most appealed to me, the computer. I used a Raspberry Pi model 3+ to power the system along with a TV screen, an audio controller that powers 2 speakers near the marquee, and a set of arcade buttons and joystick for each player. It is designed for 2 players but I’m thinking of a way to attached a temporary set of arcade buttons and joysticks to the sides the cabinet and make it a temporary 4 player set up too.

Now the building is complete and just need to find a good forever home for the system because I only realized after it was built, how large and heavy it can be.

item.title: Built a PC
item.dc:creator: Vince
item.description: In the year of 2017, I decided to build my first computer. I started doing research online about the steps to build them from the ground up starting with the motherboard, CPU, RAM, GPU, etc. I thought the task of finding the parts was going to be a challenge for me but I discovered a […]
item.content:encoded:
In the year of 2017, I decided to build my first computer. I started doing research online about the steps to build them from the ground up starting with the motherboard, CPU, RAM, GPU, etc. I thought the task of finding the parts was going to be a challenge for me but I discovered a website called TigerDirect that sold bare bone kits that simplified the process. It was a mid-level kit at the time and I found many ways to make improvements to it. I included a CD drive, Blu-ray Drive, 4 TB of storage, and upgraded the GPU once I realized that the one that came in the kit was a few years old and did not support many high end video games.

Wiki

  • Motherboard
  • CPU – Central Processing Unit
  • RAM – Random Access Memory
  • GPU – Graphic Processing Unit
  • CD Drive – Compact Disc Drive
  • Blu-Ray Drive
  • TB – Terabyte
